NODE_TEXT:
This can be achieved by forces acting on the element and these forces will correspond to the pressures surrounding the element and external forces, Fₙₑₜ acting directly on the element. Examples of such external forces could be friction in fluids flowing in pipes and ducts or the forces applied by the compressor rotor blade to the fluid. To develop equations to describe the effect of such forces on the movement of the element, the laws of conservation of momentum are used in the form of Newton’s Second Law of Motion, which states that the rate of change of momentum is equal to the net force acting on an object or, in this case, the fluid element.
